And um to see why that is, you know, we can imagine that we can measure genes, you know, the existence of genes. Anyway, um what to make with this data is a different matter. So the general approach had been then in the past, in order to try to pinpoint culture is to take away the signal and the factors from other um uh areas. So, for example, to try to find, if you control for, if you measure and, and um adjust for genetic differences, and if you measure and control for environmental differences between populations, if you do both of these things, the idea is that what is left over, if there is some difference, still left over between these populations, that you can call that difference um cut. So it's an approach that the philosophers call an X Negativo approach. It's basically defining uh something by uh the absence of all the other things. Um And that is what, what culture has been uh come to be seen. And also in the apes, I can talk more later, maybe about this, but population differences between apes that are not very obviously linked to genetic differences and um environmental differences, that's what people call ape culture.

speaker: Ricardo Lopes
